body_text.text: Phototherapy is a safe and effective treatment for many dermatologic conditions. With the advent 26 of novel biologics and small molecule inhibitors, it is important to critically evaluate the role of 27 phototherapy in dermatology. Surveys have shown that many dermatology residency programs 28 do not dedicate time to teach residents how to prescribe or administer phototherapy. Limitations 29 of phototherapy include access to a center, time required for treatments, and insurance approval. 30
Home phototherapy, a viable option, is also underutilized. However, it should be emphasized 31 that modern phototherapy has been in use for over 40 years, has an excellent safety profile, and 32

does not require laboratory monitoring. It can be safely combined with many other treatment 33 modalities including biologics and small molecule inhibitors. In addition, phototherapy costs 34 significantly less than these novel agents. Dermatologists are the only group of physicians who 35 have the expertise and proper training to deliver this treatment modality to our patients. 36
Therefore, in order to continue to deliver high quality, cost-effective care, it is imperative that 37 phototherapy be maintained as an integral part of the dermatology treatment armamentarium.
In other parts of the world, phototherapy utilization was higher than in the U.S. In 63

Australia, a nationwide survey of practicing dermatologists published in 2002 revealed that 71% 64 of respondents provided phototherapy, and among them, almost 90% had their own treatment 65 facilities. 7 In France, the number of UV treatments administered annually increased by 12% from 66 2007-2010 -nearly a decade after biologics were first introduced; however, follow-up data 67 (2013-2016) saw a decline of the same by 15%, which was attributed to delays in initiation of 68 biologic therapy. 8 Although "clinical inertia" was suggested as a reason for this delay, 8, 9 it is 69 also worthwhile to consider that many guidelines do not endorse biologics as first-line agents and 70 a stepwise approach is still advocated. 10 71 72

A 2017 study by Goyal et al. showed that there was a disparity between the demand for 74 phototherapy and the time devoted to learning it during residency. Responses obtained from 75 dermatology program directors across the U.S. revealed that a majority (67%) regarded their 76 phototherapy training as inadequate, which was primarily attributed to time deficiency. 11 77 A cross-sectional survey among U.S. dermatology residents, published in 2015, revealed 78 that about 59% did not obtain any hands-on phototherapy training, while 42% have never 79 observed phototherapy at all. Less than half of the residents felt that they could comfortably 80 administer NB-UVB unsupervised, and less than 20% were comfortable with administering other 81 modalities (excimer laser, PUVA, and BB-UVB). 12 76% were not comfortable with prescribing outpatient and home phototherapy, respectively. This 84 discomfort stemmed from a lack of exposure and is significant because dermatology trainees 85 who do not develop enough confidence to prescribe phototherapy during residency are less likely 86 to do so in practice. 13 immunosuppression. 14-16 95

Phototherapy has been used successfully to treat many skin diseases. A partial list is 96 shown in Table I . Among these, phototherapy for psoriasis has the most data. The different 97 modalities that can be used for psoriasis are BB-UVB, NB-UVB, excimer light or laser, and 98 PUVA (oral, topical, hand-foot soak, and bath/full body soak). 17 BB-UVB is rarely used 99 nowadays and has largely been replaced by NB-UVB due to the latter's better efficacy. 18 100 (79%) but caused symptomatic erythema and blistering in 17% of patients. NB-UVB attained a 106 68% CR and was better tolerated (side effects in 7.8%), while bath PUVA was the least effective 107 (58% CR) and least tolerated (side effects in 21%). Hence, although oral PUVA is more 108 efficacious, better tolerability makes NB-UVB a preferred first-line phototherapy modality. 17 In The price of treatment is a reality that must be considered when formulating a 184 management plan; and for chronic skin conditions, this may entail lifelong expenditures. 185

According to a study in Scotland, the average price for a course of NB-UVB is £257, while 186 topical medications cost £128 annually per patient. Implementing NB-UVB resulted in a 40% 187 reduction in cost (£50.74 per patient annually) due to less need for medications. 32 In practice, treatments are often combined to enhance efficacy when rapid suppression of 208 disease activity is desired or when monotherapy is insufficient to achieve and maintain control. 209 Several reviews and guidelines on psoriasis treatment have reported on the combination of 210 phototherapy with various topical drugs, traditional systemic agents, and biologics. 14, 16, 38, 39 211

With each medication having its own side effects, enhanced toxicity from combining two or 212 more modalities is a possibility. Contrarily, some combinations of medications may lower the 213 chances of long-term adverse effects by reducing the cumulative dose of either modality alone or 214

The concomitant administration of acitretin with NB-UVB has been found to hasten 217 clinical response, reduce the required acitretin dose, and decrease the number of phototherapy 218 sessions by approximately 20% thereby lowering the cumulative UV dose and theoretical risk for 219 photocarcinogenesis. 14, 38, 40 Similar effects have been observed with acitretin plus PUVA, and 220

given the established skin cancer risk with this modality, the co-administration of an oral retinoid 221 is particularly valuable. 40-43 Since retinoids have a keratolytic effect, phototherapy dose 222 escalations must be proceeded with cautiously when using this combination. 14 Most protocols 223 recommend UV dose reduction by 33%. 224

Several studies have shown that NB-UVB in conjunction with biologics is safe, 225 synergistic, and well-tolerated, although long-term data on these combinations have not been Phototherapy remains an indispensable treatment option for many cutaneous diseases. Its 265 versatility, cost-effectiveness, and unparalleled safety makes it a viable first-line treatment or 266 adjunct when other treatment regimens fall short. Just as there are numerous indications for 267 phototherapy alone, there are a wide variety of modalities with which it can be combined. As 268 dermatologic management becomes more individualized and costly, improved access to this 269 treatment modality through expanding residency training curriculums and prescribing home 270 devices will prove that even in the era of biologics, phototherapy will stand the test of time. 271

Dermatologists are the only group of physicians who have the knowledge and expertise to 272 supervise the delivery of phototherapy. Therefore, it is essential that we as a specialty continue to 273 make sure this treatment option is available to our patients.

FIGREF1.text: 109 practice, the high cost and intermittent availability of 8-methoxypsoralen in the U.S., together 110 with well-known, long-term side effects of photoaging and photocarcinogenesis, have further 111 limited the utilization of PUVA. 112 Excimer laser or excimer light is a form of targeted UVB. It limits UV exposure to the 113 involved areas only, making it ideal for localized disease (less than 10% body surface area) as 114 well as difficult-to-treat areas like the scalp, palms, and soles. 4 It can produce results with as 115 little as eight treatment sessions as compared to conventional NB-UVB, thereby reducing the 116 cumulative UV dose. 4, 18 117Outside the realm of psoriasis, NB-UVB is a first-line UV-based treatment option for 118 many conditions including vitiligo, early mycosis fungoides, and atopic dermatitis. UVA1 119 penetrates deeper into the dermis and has demonstrated benefit for sclerosing skin disorders such 120 as morphea and scleroderma. 19 NB-UVB and UVA1 are also useful for therapeutic hardening of 121 patients with polymorphous light eruption and solar urticaria, respectively. 20 For treatment-122 resistant dermatitis of the hands and feet, topical PUVA is frequently used. Oral PUVA is helpful 123 for plaque stage mycosis fungoides, other forms of cutaneous lymphoma, and as a second-line inadequately to NB-UVB.21  The list of photo-responsive dermatoses is long which underscores 126 the versatility of this treatment modality.127 Biologics are injected or infused monoclonal antibodies that block specific pro-128 inflammatory cytokines or receptors implicated in the pathophysiology of psoriasis and other 129 inflammatory diseases. 16, 22 These agents are grouped according to their cytokine target(s) as 130 follows: tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitors (etanercept, infliximab, adalimumab, 131 certolizumab), interleukin (IL)-12/IL-23 inhibitor (ustekinumab), IL-17 inhibitors (secukinumab, 132 ixekizumab, brodalumab), and IL-23 inhibitors (guselkumab, tildrakizumab, risankizumab-133 rzaa). 22 A 2019 meta-analysis found risankizumab-rzaa to be the most efficacious biologic for 134 psoriasis, followed by ixekizumab, guselkumab, and brodalumab. 23 Kim et al noted that IL-17 135 inhibitors have the earliest onset of efficacy. The fastest, brodalumab, attained a 50% reduction 136 in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index score (PASI 50) in less than 2 weeks and PASI 75 in 4 137 weeks. The IL-17 inhibitors were also among the biologic agents that had the most sustained 138 activity together with the IL-23 inhibitors and IL-12/23 inhibitor. 24 139 A comparative study by Inzinger et al. showed that the efficacy rates of oral PUVA were 140 comparable to infliximab, and exceeded those of etanercept, efalizumab, alefacept, adalimumab, 141 and ustekinumab. 25 Additionally, a recent trial comparing patient reported outcomes of NB-UVB 142 versus adalimumab versus placebo revealed that improvements in overall health-related quality 143 of life scores were equivalent for both active interventions after 12 weeks. 26 144 145 Safety and Side Effect Profile 146 tenderness, erythema, tanning, and blister formation. 18 For PUVA, the application or ingestion of 148 a photosensitizer can incite skin phototoxicity, nausea, and/or vomiting. 18 The true risk of UV-149 induced skin cancer has long been a subject of debate and is a cause of hesitation for patients and 150 providers alike. PUVA has been found to significantly increase the risk of squamous cell 151 carcinoma in a dose-dependent manner, while the incidence of PUVA-induced melanoma and 152 basal cell carcinoma is much lower. 14, 27 NB-UVB and UVA1 have had no evidence of increased 153 risk of photocarcinogenesis and are considered safe with proper supervision by most 154 practitioners. 14, 27, 28 155 These risks can be mitigated via thoughtful patient and modality selection, proper dosing 156 and dose adjustment, protection of uninvolved areas, monitoring of cumulative UV dose, and 157 periodic full body skin examinations. 14 With the exception of PUVA, phototherapy does not 158 require any pre-treatment laboratory workup and can be safely administered to pediatric, elderly, 159 and pregnant patients. 160 The side effects and safety of biologic medications should also be considered. With 161 proper patient screening, biologics have demonstrated good safety, particularly when compared 162 to traditional systemic agents; 24 however, long-term data is scarce. Patients on biologics have an 163 increased risk of infections due to the immunomodulatory effects of the medication. TNF 164 inhibitors have specifically been associated with an elevated risk of tuberculosis, hepatitis B, 165 lymphoma, and other malignancies, while IL-17 inhibitors have been shown to induce and 166 exacerbate inflammatory bowel disease, and increase the risk for mucocutaneous candidiasis. 24, 29 167 Depression and suicidality have been reported among patients on brodalumab, although evidence To minimize these risks, patients who are candidates for biologic therapy require workup 171 prior to initiation and at regular intervals throughout treatment. Laboratory tests consisting of a 172 complete blood count, liver function test, hepatitis panel, and tuberculosis screening are regularly 173 performed. 22, 30 Additional tests may be warranted depending on patient-specific or medication-174 specific risk factors. Recent guidelines suggest that certain biologic agents may be safely 175 administered to pregnant, lactating, and pediatric patients; however, information regarding this is 176 still limited. 22, 31 177The COVID-19 pandemic raised numerous questions regarding biologics' safety, which 178 lack clear, evidence-based answers. The least expensive biologic included in the study, adalimumab, was quoted at 190 $23,538 for the first year of therapy alone compared to $3,148 and $7,582 for a year of NB-UVB fold ($58,045) for the first year of therapy alone. 34 193 Home phototherapy units cost anywhere between $2,500 and $5,000. 35, 36 They can offset 194 the indirect expenses incurred from office-based treatment (transportation, lost income from 195 work absences, inconvenience), but a disadvantage is that patients must pay for the device 196 upfront as few insurance policies offer coverage. A comparative study revealed that while in-197 office phototherapy was less costly at the beginning of treatment, it became five times more 198 expensive than home phototherapy after 3 months. 36 Additionally, when compared to biologics, 199 home phototherapy costs up to 36 times less over a 3-year period. 37 200 Biologics have remarkable efficacy, a good safety record to date, and are convenient to 201administer. This may provide rationale for physicians and patients to justify the high cost, 202 especially when factoring in the intangible phototherapy expenses. However, some patients may 203 respond inadequately to biologic therapy and require dose escalation or more frequent 204 administration, thereby further increasing the cost of treatment.

Patients with moderate to severe psoriasis who complied with thrice weekly NB-UVB 227 in addition to etanercept demonstrated biopsy-proven improvement without additional adverse 228 effects compared to etanercept alone. 38, 44 Moreover, a half-body comparison of adalimumab plus 229 NB-UVB versus adalimumab alone yielded a 33% greater PASI reduction on the irradiated body 230 half compared to the non-irradiated half. 45 Analogous results were obtained in a similar trial on 231 ustekinumab. 46 Erythema was the most common side effect. 45, 46 To date, there are no studies on 232 the combination of PUVA with any biologic. 41 233 234 Limitations of Phototherapy 235 One major challenge concerning adherence to phototherapy is limited access. In the U.S., 236 phototherapy facilities are concentrated in urban areas of the East and West Coasts and the misdistribution appears to reflect the geographic location of dermatology providers in general 239 and not the underutilization of phototherapy per se. Nonetheless, the indirect costs of travel and 240 lost income from missing work can discourage patients from complying with repeated 241 phototherapy treatments. 6 Other limiting factors are the resources needed to establish a 242 phototherapy center (equipment, space, trained staff), and the need for prior authorization. 243 Home phototherapy devices can potentially address these hurdles. Several randomized 244 trials have shown that home-based and office-based phototherapy are equally safe and effective 245with higher satisfaction and adherence in favor of home phototherapy; however, this also entails 246 higher upfront costs for the patient as well as the need for a provider who is sufficiently familiar 247 with home phototherapy. 47 In addition, phototherapy has possible long-term risks. Therefore, in 248 practice, it is usually administered intermittently, and patients may experience disease relapses 249 within weeks to months of discontinuation. Combining phototherapy with other modalities can 250 not only decrease the likelihood or severity of a relapse but also lower the risk of side effects 251 from either modality alone.
